titleStmt.title: Lung clearance index for monitoring early lung disease in alpha-1antitrypsin deficiency

affiliation.orgName: Department of Paediatrics and Research Institute

analytic.title: Lung clearance index for monitoring early lung disease in alpha-1antitrypsin deficiency

biblStruct.note: Received 8 September 2015 Received in revised form 23 March 2016 Accepted 26 April 2016

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Patients with alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency (AATD) and a PI-ZZ genotype are at high risk to develop severe emphysema during adulthood.
However, little is known about early stages of emphysema and disease manifestation in other PI-types.
Spirometry is commonly used for monitoring although early manifestation of emphysema is suspected within the peripheral airways that are not accessible by forced expiratory manoeuvres.
We hypothesized that the Lung Clearance Index (LCI) derived from multiple breath nitrogen-washout (N 2 -washout) is useful to bridge this diagnostic gap.
Patients from age 4 years onward and different PItypes performed N 2 -washout and spirometry.
Results were compared to controls.
193 patients (4e79 years, 75% PI-ZZ) and 33 controls (8e60 years) were included.
Mean (SD) LCI in patients was 9.1 (3.1) and 6.3 (0.6) in controls (p 0.001).
47% of adult patients with other than PI-ZZ genotypes and 39% of all patients with normal spirometry had abnormal LCIs.

The LCI measured by N 2 -washout discriminates between patients with AATD and controls, reflects AATD related lung disease in all stages and appears to identify early peripheral lung changes in younger age than spirometry.
We conclude that a normal spirometry does not exclude presence of AATD related lung disease even in genotypes other than PI-ZZ.
The risk of developing alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency (AATD) related emphysema during adulthood is very high in patients with a PI-ZZ genotype.
Data regarding onset and progression of early lung changes as well as knowledge about the risk to develop emphysema for patients with other than a PI-ZZ genotype are limited.
The forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV 1 ) and the ratio FEV 1 /FVC derived from spirometry are the primary parameters for detecting and tracking AATD related airway obstruction.
FEV 1 is additionally used for initiating and monitoring alpha-1-antitrypsin (AAT) augmentation therapy [1e4].
However, manifestation of emphysema is first expected within the peripheral airways [1] beyond the 8th bronchus generation that are not reflected by spirometry [5].

This may explain why many patients report clinical symptoms such as shortness of breath, reduced physical activity and cough despite normal spirometry [6,7] and why follow-up of the Swedish AATD birth cohort showed ongoing normal spirometry [6,8,9].
AATD related worsening of lung function may progress rapidly once functional deterioration has started ("rapid decliners").

It is likely that AATD related lung disease starts long before deterioration of spirometry and that a decline in FEV 1 and FEV 1 /FVC respectively reflects advanced disease rather than initial changes.
Computed chest tomography (CT) and CT densitometry have shown to be sensitive for detecting emphysema and for monitoring response to augmentation therapy in patients with AATD [1,3,10].
However, routine use is limited due to radiation exposure, particularly in younger patients [11].

Multiple breath nitrogen washout (N 2 -washout) technique is sensitive yet non-invasive for assessing overall ventilation inhomogeneity (VI) of the lungs and particularly changes within the peripheral airways.
The extent of VI can be quantified by calculating the Lung Clearance Index (LCI) from the N 2 -washout curves.
An increase of the LCI indicates presence of VI. [12].

Previous studies in patients with Cystic Fibrosis demonstrated that the LCI is a robust and reproducible parameter [13] that identifies early peripheral lung disease more often than spirometry and before clinical symptoms become apparent [14e16].

In CF, the LCI correlated with structural changes observed in CT-scans [17e19], was of prognostic value for the progression of lung disease [20,21] and was suitable for monitoring the effect of therapeutic interventions [22,23].
Few studies have shown that N 2 -washout may also be interesting in other respiratory diseases where the small airways are affected [24].
We hypothesized that VI may be present in patients with AATD before clinical symptoms occur or FEV 1 deteriorates.
Close monitoring of lung function and diagnosis of early lung changes using more adequate methods may subsequently lead to better prevention strategies.
There may be a window of opportunity to stop disease or slow progression.
Monitoring AATD related lung disease only through spirometry may lead to missing this time gap.

This study on N 2 -washout in patients with AATD aimed to assess whether the LCI is suitable to detect pulmonary changes in patients with AATD in all stages and in patients with different genotypes, and whether the LCI detects initial lung changes at a younger age and more often than spirometry.
This is a prospective, cross sectional and multi-centre study in children, adolescents and adults with a confirmed diagnosis of AATD.
Patients with a PI-ZZ genotype (4e80 years) and adult patients with other PI-types and a blood level of AAT < 90 mg/dl were recruited.
Inclusion was independent of clinical symptoms and risk factors such as asthma and tobacco smoke exposure.

Patient recruitment was supported by the German Alpha-1-Registry, the European Alpha-1 foundation and the German Alpha-1 patient organisations who forwarded study information and contact details of the leading study centre to their members.
Additional recruitment was performed from the newborn screening program in South Tyrol.
N 2 -washout data in controls (4e80 years) are consecutively collected at the Marien Hospital Wesel since 2012 in order to generate a reference data set covering all age groups.
Volunteers were eligible if they had no history of active and/or passive smoking and/or no history of any chronic or acute respiratory disease.
Demographic data of patients and controls and patient characteristics are summarized in Tables 1 and 2.
Informed written consent and, where appropriate, assent was obtained prior to all measurements.

The study was carried out in accordance with the amended Declaration of Helsinki between November 2011 and March 2013, was approved by the ethics committee of the leading study centre in Hannover, Germany (Project number 2801) and was registered by the local ethics committees of the cooperating study centres.
Eligible patients were recruited for a single study visit.
Following measurement of weight and height all participants filled in a questionnaire regarding their medical history, level of AAT, PIgenotype and social background.
Lung function assessment included 2e3 technically acceptable N 2 -washouts [12] and subsequent spirometry.
All tests were performed according to internal standard operating procedures.
Lung function results were then compared to our reference data set.
N 2 -washout tests were performed using the EasyOne Pro LAB™ (ndd medical technologies AG, Zurich, Switzerland).
The device is based on the ultrasonic technology that was described previously [25] and has been licensed for clinical use in January 2012.

Briefly, the system consists of a mainstream ultrasonic transducer for flow sampling, a side stream ultrasonic transducer for temperature independent sampling of the molar mass and a side stream infrared CO 2 analyzer (DUET ETCO2 Module, Welch Allyn OEM Technologies, Beaverton).
A gas bias flow system allows valve-controlled delivery of 100% medical oxygen during the N 2 -washout phase [13,26].
Automated quality control is provided according to published criteria [12].
An algorithm for time delay correction of the side stream signals is implemented as described previously [26] and is automatically applied prior to analysis.
Algorithms for automated calculation of functional residual capacity (FRC) and LCI are implemented according to recent recommendations.
Briefly, the FRC is calculated from the cumulative expired volume of expired nitrogen divided by the difference between end-tidal gas concentration at the start and end of the washout.
The LCI is calculated as the cumulative expired volume divided by the FRC.
The LCI represents the number of expired lung volumes needed to reduce the N 2 concentration to 1/40 of its starting level [12].
To start a measurement, subjects breathe quietly through the mouthpiece while wearing a nose clip.
After sampling of approximately 5 regular breaths of room air the bias flow is automatically switched to the oxygen supply at end expiration.
Inspiration of 100% oxygen then causes a breath by breath washout of N 2 from the lungs.
The washout phase is finished when the N 2 concentration has fallen below 1/40 of its starting level.
EasyWarePro © software (version 1.6.0.1.0)
was used for data acquisition, storage and analysis.
Spirometry was performed according to ATS/ERS standards [27] using the EasyOne Pro LAB™, ndd Medizintechnik AG, Zurich, Switzerland.
Primary outcomes were the forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV 1 ), the ratio FEV 1 /FVC and the forced expiratory flow at 75% expired volume (FEF 75 ).
Calculation of standard deviation scores (z-scores) for the spirometric parameters are based on published regression equations by the Global Lung Initiative [28].
Heart rate and oxygen saturation were assessed using standard pulse oxymetry.
Group data for age, weight, height, BMI, FEV 1 -z, FEV 1 /FVC and FEF 75 -z are reported as mean and standard deviation (SD).
Individual data for the LCI are reported as the mean (SD) of 2e3 measurements for each subject.
Group data are then again expressed as mean (SD).
According to the recommendations of the Global Lung Initiative the lower limit of normal for the spirometric parameters was set to À1.64 SD.
The upper limit of normal of the LCI was defined as mean LCI for the group þ1.64 SD [28].
P-values and 95% confidence intervals derived from unpaired ttests were used to compare patients and controls and smokers and non-smokers respectively.
Pearson correlations were used to assess the dependence of the LCI on spirometric parameters, breathing frequency, tidal volume and demographic values.
The statistical package used was SPSS version 21.0 for Windows.
N ¼ 238 patients participated in the study.
45/238 patients (21%) were excluded due to screening failure (n ¼ 19), missing data (n ¼ 1) and technically inacceptable N 2 -washout tests (n ¼ 25).
Reasons for technically inacceptable N 2 -washout tests were mainly lacking compliance in preschool children or that the patients were too ill to achieve sufficient test quality.193/238
patients were included into final analysis.
33 controls were selected [29] from our reference data set for comparison with the AATD population.

Demographic data of patients and controls and patient characteristics are summarized in Tables 1 and 2 LCI, FEV 1 and FEV 1 /FVC differed significantly between patients and controls, while FRC, tidal volume per kilogram bodyweight (TV/kg), breaths per minute (BPM) and FEF 75 did not (Table 3).
For quality control it is important to note that the LCI was not dependent on TV/kg (p ¼ 0.948) or BPM (p ¼ 0.349).

FEV 1 was normal until the end of the fourth decade except for one adolescent with a history of severe lower respiratory tract infections and two children with reduced lung volumes but normal FEV 1 /FVC.
In contrast, the LCI discriminates between controls and patients throughout and increases markedly with age in the latter (p 0.001) (Fig. 1).
Even in patients younger than 40 years of age the LCI differed from healthy controls (6.3 and 6.9; mean difference -0.6; 95% CI -1.1; -0.1; p¼0.019).
VI reflected by an increased LCI is also present in patients with PI-types other than PI-ZZ who commonly have higher blood levels of AAT (e.g.
PI-MZ) (Fig. 2).
83% of adults with a PI-ZZ genotype and 47% of adults with other than a PI-ZZ genotype had abnormal LCI results.
There was a significant correlation between LCI and AAT blood levels (p ¼ 0.003).
In Fig. 3 individual LCI results are plotted against individual FEV 1 -z-scores.
The upper left section contains those patients, where LCI and FEV 1 were abnormal (n ¼ 69).
These are the patients with known lung disease that is also reflected by an elevated LCI.
There are only two patients with a normal LCI and a slightly decreased FEV 1 (lower left section).
The upper and lower right sections contain n ¼ 117 patients with a normal FEV 1. Out of these, n ¼ 45 (39%) had an abnormal LCI, while n ¼ 72 (61%) had a completely normal lung function.
It is important to note, that all but two had a normal FEF 75 too.

Compared to the patients in the upper right section (FEV 1 normal, LCI increased), the patients in the upper left section (both FEV 1 and, LCI abnormal) were older (57 vs 43 years; p < 0.001); were older at diagnosis (47 vs 33 years; p < 0.001), were mainly smokers (74 vs 29%), reported more smoking pack years (17 vs. 9.5 years; p ¼ 0.047) and had lower blood levels of A1AT (41 vs 31 mg/ dL; p ¼ 0.019).
Furthermore, more patients in the upper left section were exposed to environmental tobacco smoke (57 vs 36%).
The LCI in patients with normal FEV 1 and abnormal LCI was not only slightly increased but went up to 15 LCI units.
The LCI in this subgroup was dependent on age (p 0.001) (Fig. 4), while FEV 1 was not (p ¼ 0.449).
In contrast, neither LCI nor FEV 1 were dependent on age in patients with completely normal lung function (p ¼ 0.164 and 0.828 respectively).
There was no difference in AAT blood levels, smoking pack years, passive smoking, tidal volumes, breathing frequencies, FRC and FEF 75 between the two groups.

However, respiratory symptoms at diagnosis, a history of severe airway infections and pollutant exposure were more frequent in patients with abnormal LCI results and a normal FEV 1 than in those with a completely normal lung function (56% versus 21%, 53.3 versus 43.1% and 26.7 versus 16.7% respectively).
N ¼ 106 (54.9%) of the entire study group were never-smokers and almost all smokers quit smoking when given the diagnosis.
In adults (n ¼ 150) LCI and FEV 1 differed significantly between eversmokers and never-smokers (p ¼ 0.004, 95%CI À-2.558;À0.504 and p 0.001, 95%CI 0.653; 1.816 respectively).
Furthermore n ¼ 78 (40.4%) stated previous and/or current passive smoking.
N ¼ 123 (64%) were current and/or previous passive and/or active smokers.
In adults LCI and FEV 1 differed significantly between "any-tobacco smoke" and "never-tobacco smoke" (p ¼ 0.015, 95% CI -2.771; 2.972 and p 0.001, 95% CI 0.834; 2.141 respectively).
Fig. 5A indicates that even in adult never-smokers, lung function was often severely impaired; however, comparing figure A with figure B reveals impact of passive smoking on lung function too.

This cross sectional study is the first using N 2 -washout and the LCI to assess peripheral airway function in children, adolescents The LCI discriminates between patients with AATD and healthy controls, reflects AATD related lung disease in all stages and detects initial lung changes in younger age and more often than spirometry.
Increased LCIs were not only present in patients with a PI-ZZ genotype but also in individuals with other, less severe PI-types.
For interpretation of N 2 -washout measurements in AATD, a concomitant control group was required.

In accordance with an ongoing discussion about how to define a realistic reference population for lung function assessments, our current reference data collection on N 2 -washout includes individuals with a history of active and/or passive tobacco smoke exposure and a history of acute respiratory tract infections (e.g. a single pneumonia) but excluded individuals with diagnosed chronic lung diseases and prematurity.

For the present analysis, only individuals with no history of active and/or passive tobacco smoke exposure and/or a history of severe acute respiratory diseases were selected because we aimed to detect early disease in AATD.
This selection may overestimate lung changes but is in accordance with previously published data [29].
There are a number of studies which have demonstrated that the LCI remains relatively stable independent of age.
We therefore felt it to be appropriate to rely on the smaller control group with the advantage to use very strict inclusion criteria for better discrimination.
This resulted in a lower number of older controls.

However when using reference data published by Verbanck et al., who has demonstrated a small increase of LCI with age after the 3rd decade in controls, LCI shifts from normal to slightly abnormal in only 7 patients.
This does not alter the overall message.
In accordance with other studies the majority of our study population had a normal FEV 1. [6,9,30] However, almost 40% of these had an increased LCI, which increased with age.
This supports the view that development of AATD related VI begins within the smaller airways and increases over the following years towards the larger airways.
Therefore parameters derived from spirometry, representing the more central airways, remain largely unaffected over decades.
In our population LCI was abnormal starting in early school age.

In contrast FEV 1 was normal until the end of the fourth decade except for one adolescent with a history of severe lower respiratory tract infections and two children with reduced lung volumes but normal FEV 1 /FVC.

The fact that none of the patients had normal LCI results in the presence of an abnormal FEV 1 emphasises the idea of consecutive involvement of more peripheral airways first, followed by more central airways.

Accordingly Holme et al. [30] reported worse gas transfer and health status in nonindex subjects already from age 16 and additional impaired CT densitometry from age 29 while spirometry remained normal.
Bernspång et al. [6,9] reported ongoing normal spirometry in young adults with AATD despite clinical symptoms.
We therefore postulate that VI is a better marker than FEV 1 for detecting and monitoring early lung changes in AATD [2].
However, to further investigate this hypothesis, longitudinal assessment of VI in patients with normal spirometry at study start is necessary.
Patients diagnosed with AATD during childhood or non-index subjects may benefit from longitudinal lung function assessments including N 2 -washout.
Previous studies have shown that longitudinal assessment of lung function in young asymptomatic patients allows predicting future progression to some extent [31].
Detection and monitoring of early pulmonary changes may motivate to adhere to preventive recommendations (e.g.
avoidance of tobacco smoke and other pollutants, choice of employment).
In patients with advanced lung disease additional measurement of the LCI may help to investigate treatment effects.
In accordance to previous studies [1,32,33], both, active and passive smoking influence lung function in patients with AATD.
However, severe lung disease was also present in never-smokers.
This may be explained by other triggers such as concurrent asthma or pollutant exposure [34].
It was previously shown, that in never-smokers with AATD lung impairment measured by gas transfer and CT densitometry occurs but is delayed in time when compared to smokers with A1ATD.
Current knowledge about lung disease in other than PI-ZZ genotypes is limited.
However, available data suggest that there is a risk for lung disease which manifestates later in life and which is triggered by e.g.
cigarette smoke and/or air pollutants [1,35,36].

Seersholm et al. stated, that fist degree relatives of PI-ZZ indexsubjects with a PI-MZ genotype have a familial tendency to develop COPD which is due to unknown genetic and/or environmental factors [37].
The risk for emphysema in patients with a PI-SZ genotype remains unclear but is expected to be as high as in patients with a PI-ZZ genotype [1].
In our study, almost half of the adults with other than a PI-ZZ genotype had increased LCIs while only one fifth had an impaired FEV 1 .
No one had an abnormal FEV 1 with a normal LCI.

68% of this subgroup had a history of active and/or passive tobacco smoke exposure but the proportion of abnormal LCI results was slightly lower than in the group of never smokers (44% and 53% respectively).
Interpretation of this observation is limited because the groups are small thus prohibiting a more extended analysis.
However, it may be stated that individuals with other than PI-ZZ genotypes require professional attention due to their potential risk to develop AATD related lung disease too.
The study has several limitations:
We have not been able to include imaging and/or measurements of inflammatory markers as reference methods allowing formal assessment of the sensitivity of the LCI for AATD related airway obstruction.
It could be argued that DLCO should have been measured as A1AT deficiency may lead to emphysematous changes.
However, the study was carried out in different sites and DLCO measurements were not feasible in most sites.
We therefore cannot answer the question, whether DLCO is better than spirometry for detecting early A1ATD related changes.
Matching of the control group to the patients according to age, risk factors and life style would have been ideal.
However, the normal range of the LCI is narrow and almost stable over a large part of child-and adulthood.
We therefore found it appropriate to recruit a healthy control group over approximately a similar age span.
Patient characteristics were partly derived from open questionnaires and the study population is heterogeneous with regard to age and mode of diagnosis.
Both, support from the German Alpha-1-Registry, and the multicentre study design allowed recruitment of the study population from all registered patients living in Germany.
However, only few participants between 20 and 35 years of age could be recruited who may have been patients with more severe disease.
This could explain the disproportional increase of the LCI in this age range (Fig. 1).
Asymptomatic adolescents and young adults are patients generally diagnosed during early childhood who have grown out of paediatric care.
Those who no longer have hepatic problems are commonly not transferred to an adult clinic and may therefore have been missed by our study.
However, this subpopulation could be the most important to further investigate onset and progression of early lung disease in AATD.

In addition, the present study design cannot demonstrate that all patients with abnormal LCI will develop FEV 1 changes and clinical lung disease; whether an elevated LCI in children precedes clinical lung disease in patients with AATD has to be assessed in longitudinal follow-up studies.
In summary this study presents a unique collection of cross sectional lung function data in AATD, including different genotypes and all stages of lung disease.
The study provides novel data on ventilation inhomogeneity using multiple breath washout which supports the hypothesis that pulmonary changes in AATD are present when spirometry is still normal.
We conclude that LCI measured by N 2 -washout reflects known AATD related lung disease in all stages and detects manifestation at a younger age and more often than spirometry.
Abnormal spirometry does not exclude presence of AATD related lung disease, even in other than PI-ZZ genotypes.
AATD may serve as an example for a well defined sub-group of patients with COPD.
We speculate that N 2 -washout for assessment of VI will be helpful to better understand early pulmonary changes in other forms of COPD.
Fig. 1.
Individual LCI versus age in patients and controls.
The dotted line represents the upper limit of normal for the LCI (7.2).
Patients: open circles, controls: filled circles.
Fig. 3. Individual LCI versus individual FEV 1 -z in patients.
The horizontal line represents the upper limit of normal for the LCI (7.2), the vertical line represents the lower limit of normal for the FEV 1 -z (À1.64 SD).
Fig. 4. n ¼ 45 Patients with normal FEV 1 and abnormal LCI.
The horizontal line represents the upper limit of normal for the LCI (7.2).
Fig.5. A. LCI versus age.
The horizontal line represents the upper limit of normal for the LCI (7.2).
Filled circles: "never smoker", open circles: "ever smoker" (smoker and exsmoker).
B. Individual LCI versus age.
The horizontal line represents the upper limit of normal for the LCI (7.2).
Filled circles: "never tobacco smoke", open circles: "any tobacco smoke" (smoker, ex-smoker and passive smoker).
Demographics.
Patient characteristics (n ¼ 193).

Lung function results: Lung Clearance Index (LCI), functional residual capacity (FRC), tidal volume per kg bodyweight (TV/kg), breaths per minute (BPM) and z-scores for forced expired volume in one second (FEV 1-z), Tiffeneau-Index (FEV 1 /FVC) and forced expired flow at 75% expired volume (FEF 75 -z).

body.note: S.I. Fuchs et al. / Respiratory Medicine 116 (2016) 93e99

p.s: We would like to thank our patients and their families for taking part in this study and the German Alpha-1-Registry (R. Kardorff), the European Alpha-1 Foundation (E.
Takahashi) and the German Alpha-1 patient organisations (G.
Niethammer, G. Beier) for ongoing support in patient recruitment.
Monika Gappa and Susanne Fuchs were responsible for study conception, study coordination, patient recruitment, original data collection, data analysis and manuscript preparation.
All co-authors agreed to be accountable for all aspects of the work and reviewed the final manuscript.

Additionally, Nicolaus Schwerk contributed to conception of the study, patient recruitment and original data collection; Klaus Pittschieler, Frank Ahrens, Winfried Baden, Wolfgang Gleiber, Matthias Griese, Georg Hülskamp, Thomas K€ ohnlein, Ludmilla Reckling, Ernst Rietschel, and Doris Staab contributed to patient recruitment and original data collection; and Robert Bals and Sebastian F€ ahndrich contributed to patient recruitment.
This study was supported by an unrestricted grant from Grifols GmbH Frankfurt a.M., Germany (former Talecris).
The study is investigator initiated and the company had no influence on the design, selection of collaborating centers, performance, analysis or interpretation of the study.
Ndd Medical Technologies (Zurich, Switzesrland) provided equipment and disposables.
S. Fuchs and M. Gappa received a speaker honoraria from Grifols/Talecris and S. Fuchs was invited for the annual meeting of the European Respiratory Society 2010 and 2011.
The other authors declare that they don't have a real or perceived conflict of interest.
